dict.string: Very few of her nearly 1,800 poems were published during her lifetime, mostly anonymously and without her knowledge.
After she passed away, her younger sister found hundreds of her poems and helped publish them beginning in 1890.
Although her acquaintances were aware of her writing, she was protective of it by hiding it in a locked chest.
She had a greenhouse built in her homestead so that she could indulge her passion for gardening all year round.
She was engaged to a student at Amherst College, but her father broke it off because he was just a poor student.
She called the treatment for her painful eye condition "eight months of Siberia" because she was forbidden to read.
She wrote on envelopes and other scrap paper, suggesting that she wrote down ideas for poems wherever she was inspired.
Her writing features dense syntax and unusual vocabulary, which makes her poetry intriguing but hard to understand.
Her father led a disciplined and civic-minded life, serving both in the state legislature and in Congress.
With her bedroom window facing a local cemetery, she saw frequent burials as a young girl.
In her last years, she endured the loss of several close friends and family members, including her mother and nephew.
She largely withdrew from social life by her late twenties, and this period proved to be her most productive period.
